Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Situation2: They are approached by a member facing a difficult life choice and need to give thoughtful guidance.
Story: I was folding the last of the towels when my phone buzzed. It was Sarah from church, her message urgent: “Can you talk? I really need your advice.” I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket, the kids’ soccer uniforms still buried somewhere inside. My husband had asked if I could make sure everything was ready for tomorrow’s busy day. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family counting on me to keep things running smoothly, and Sarah, vulnerable and searching, needing her pastor’s wisdom. I could hear the washing machine’s chime, reminding me of the chores left undone, while my heart ached for Sarah’s pain. I wanted to be present for my family, to share the load and show my love in these small, daily ways. But I also felt the sacred pull of my calling, the responsibility to guide and comfort those who trust me. My hands trembled as I held the phone, torn between the demands of home and the needs of my congregation, unsure which voice to answer first.
